properties.Situation_Snapshot: By mid-January 2026, Madagascar reported 290 mpox (clade Ib) cases across 18 regions with 78 confirmed; most cases (180) were in Boeny region. Travel-associated cases have been detected in Mayotte, Spain and the UK, indicating limited international spread.
properties.Travel_Takeaways: Risk to general travellers is low, but men who have sex with men should be aware of mpox symptoms. Practise good hygiene and avoid close contact with individuals exhibiting mpox-like symptoms; vaccination may be considered for those at high risk.
properties.General_Recommendations: Travellers should consider vaccination (when available) and speak with their healthcare provider before travel; practise insect bite prevention by using repellent, wearing long-sleeved clothing and sleeping under nets; practise food and water hygiene by eating only fully cooked food and boiled or treated water; avoid contact with sick people, bats, rodents and other wild or domestic animals and their excreta; avoid visiting live animal markets, caves and mines, and do not consume bushmeat or unpasteurised products; practise safe sex and avoid unnecessary medical or cosmetic procedures; carry a travel health kit and comprehensive travel insurance including medical evacuation; seek prompt medical advice if you develop fever, rash or other symptoms during or after travel.

properties.Situation_Snapshot: Level 2 travel alert: outbreaks of clade II monkeypox in Ghana and Liberia affect men and women equally and primarily spread through intimate contact. CDC advises travellers to consider the two‑dose JYNNEOS vaccine and avoid close contact with symptomatic people, contaminated materials and wild animals.
properties.Travel_Takeaways: Travellers engaging in sexual or intimate contact in Ghana and Liberia should get vaccinated with two doses of JYNNEOS and practise safer sex. Avoid handling or consuming bush meat and interacting with wild primates or rodents.
properties.General_Recommendations: Travellers should consider vaccination (when available) and speak with their healthcare provider before travel; practise insect bite prevention by using repellent, wearing long-sleeved clothing and sleeping under nets; practise food and water hygiene by eating only fully cooked food and boiled or treated water; avoid contact with sick people, bats, rodents and other wild or domestic animals and their excreta; avoid visiting live animal markets, caves and mines, and do not consume bushmeat or unpasteurised products; practise safe sex and avoid unnecessary medical or cosmetic procedures; carry a travel health kit and comprehensive travel insurance including medical evacuation; seek prompt medical advice if you develop fever, rash or other symptoms during or after travel.

properties.Situation_Snapshot: Two healthcare workers in Kolkata were diagnosed with Nipah virus in January 2026; all 196 contacts tested negative and there is no evidence of community transmission. This is the first Nipah outbreak in West Bengal in 19 years.
properties.Travel_Takeaways: Avoid contact with bats and sick people, do not drink raw date palm sap and practise hand hygiene; there is no vaccine, so prevention is essential.
properties.General_Recommendations: Travellers should consider vaccination (when available) and speak with their healthcare provider before travel; practise insect bite prevention by using repellent, wearing long-sleeved clothing and sleeping under nets; practise food and water hygiene by eating only fully cooked food and boiled or treated water; avoid contact with sick people, bats, rodents and other wild or domestic animals and their excreta; avoid visiting live animal markets, caves and mines, and do not consume bushmeat or unpasteurised products; practise safe sex and avoid unnecessary medical or cosmetic procedures; carry a travel health kit and comprehensive travel insurance including medical evacuation; seek prompt medical advice if you develop fever, rash or other symptoms during or after travel.

properties.Situation_Snapshot: Argentina reported a confirmed case of Argentine haemorrhagic fever in Santa Fe province on 16 January 2026; Junin virus remains endemic in several central provinces and cases usually occur during harvest season.
properties.Travel_Takeaways: Travellers visiting rural endemic regions should avoid rodent-infested areas and contact with rodent excreta, use insect bite precautions and ensure vaccinations are up to date.
properties.General_Recommendations: Travellers should consider vaccination (when available) and speak with their healthcare provider before travel; practise insect bite prevention by using repellent, wearing long-sleeved clothing and sleeping under nets; practise food and water hygiene by eating only fully cooked food and boiled or treated water; avoid contact with sick people, bats, rodents and other wild or domestic animals and their excreta; avoid visiting live animal markets, caves and mines, and do not consume bushmeat or unpasteurised products; practise safe sex and avoid unnecessary medical or cosmetic procedures; carry a travel health kit and comprehensive travel insurance including medical evacuation; seek prompt medical advice if you develop fever, rash or other symptoms during or after travel.

properties.Situation_Snapshot: Three new human infections with low‑pathogenic avian influenza A(H9N2) were reported in China between 9 and 15 January 2026: two children from Jiangxi and Yunnan exposed to backyard poultry and one child from Beijing exposed at a live bird market; all recovered.
properties.Travel_Takeaways: Avoid visiting live bird markets or backyard poultry farms; practise good hand hygiene and only eat thoroughly cooked poultry and eggs; seek medical advice if respiratory symptoms develop.
properties.General_Recommendations: Travellers should consider vaccination (when available) and speak with their healthcare provider before travel; practise insect bite prevention by using repellent, wearing long-sleeved clothing and sleeping under nets; practise food and water hygiene by eating only fully cooked food and boiled or treated water; avoid contact with sick people, bats, rodents and other wild or domestic animals and their excreta; avoid visiting live animal markets, caves and mines, and do not consume bushmeat or unpasteurised products; practise safe sex and avoid unnecessary medical or cosmetic procedures; carry a travel health kit and comprehensive travel insurance including medical evacuation; seek prompt medical advice if you develop fever, rash or other symptoms during or after travel.

properties.Situation_Snapshot: Since the beginning of 2025, and as of 5 January 2026, 19 MERS‑CoV cases (including four deaths) have been reported, mostly in Saudi Arabia, with some cases linked to camel exposure; no community transmission has been detected and the risk to Europe remains low.
properties.Travel_Takeaways: Avoid contact with camels and camel products, practise hand and respiratory hygiene and seek medical care if you develop fever and cough; travellers with underlying conditions should be especially cautious.
properties.General_Recommendations: Travellers should consider vaccination (when available) and speak with their healthcare provider before travel; practise insect bite prevention by using repellent, wearing long-sleeved clothing and sleeping under nets; practise food and water hygiene by eating only fully cooked food and boiled or treated water; avoid contact with sick people, bats, rodents and other wild or domestic animals and their excreta; avoid visiting live animal markets, caves and mines, and do not consume bushmeat or unpasteurised products; practise safe sex and avoid unnecessary medical or cosmetic procedures; carry a travel health kit and comprehensive travel insurance including medical evacuation; seek prompt medical advice if you develop fever, rash or other symptoms during or after travel.

properties.Situation_Snapshot: Sri Lanka continues to experience an outbreak of chikungunya, a mosquito-borne viral illness causing fever and joint pain; travellers can be infected via daytime‑biting mosquitoes and there is no specific treatment.
properties.Travel_Takeaways: Vaccination is recommended for eligible travellers and pregnant travellers should consult a healthcare provider or avoid travel. Prevent mosquito bites by using insect repellent, wearing long sleeves and staying in screened or air-conditioned areas.
properties.General_Recommendations: Travellers should consider vaccination (when available) and speak with their healthcare provider before travel; practise insect bite prevention by using repellent, wearing long-sleeved clothing and sleeping under nets; practise food and water hygiene by eating only fully cooked food and boiled or treated water; avoid contact with sick people, bats, rodents and other wild or domestic animals and their excreta; avoid visiting live animal markets, caves and mines, and do not consume bushmeat or unpasteurised products; practise safe sex and avoid unnecessary medical or cosmetic procedures; carry a travel health kit and comprehensive travel insurance including medical evacuation; seek prompt medical advice if you develop fever, rash or other symptoms during or after travel.

properties.Situation_Snapshot: Ethiopia declared the end of its first Marburg virus disease outbreak on 26 January 2026 after 42 days without new cases; the outbreak, first detected in November 2025, resulted in 19 cases (14 confirmed and five probable) and 14 deaths, with all 857 contacts completing follow‑up.
properties.Travel_Takeaways: Risk is minimal now the outbreak is over, but visitors should still avoid contact with fruit bats and people showing haemorrhagic symptoms; practise good hygiene and follow local health advisories.
properties.General_Recommendations: Travellers should consider vaccination (when available) and speak with their healthcare provider before travel; practise insect bite prevention by using repellent, wearing long-sleeved clothing and sleeping under nets; practise food and water hygiene by eating only fully cooked food and boiled or treated water; avoid contact with sick people, bats, rodents and other wild or domestic animals and their excreta; avoid visiting live animal markets, caves and mines, and do not consume bushmeat or unpasteurised products; practise safe sex and avoid unnecessary medical or cosmetic procedures; carry a travel health kit and comprehensive travel insurance including medical evacuation; seek prompt medical advice if you develop fever, rash or other symptoms during or after travel.
